results.title: Blade II
results.creator_credit: New Line Cinema, Peter Frankfurt, Wesley Snipes, Patrick Palmer and Guillermo del Toro
results.brief_description: Based on Marvel Comics more dark super hero franchise, “Blade II” chronicles the adventures of a half human, half vampire (Wesley Snipes) who diligently protects humans from the seething vampire underworld. Mexican horror director Guillermo del Toro (The Devil’s backbone, Cronos) has fashioned a faithful sequel which delves deeper into the vampire mythology set up in the first film while maintaining the series penchant for blood soaked martial arts action. Set in Prague (its gothic buildings and ancient cobblestoned streets make this a fitting location for a vampire movie), “Blade II“‘s action takes off when a new breed of vampires are discovered, the Deadly Reapers. These nasty nightcrawlers not only feed on humans but are not impartial to vampire blood as well. This causes the worried vampire fraternity (known as the Shadow Council) to form an uneasy alliance with arch-enemy Blade and his gruff side-kick Whistler (Kris Kristofferson). Together they must hunt down and destroy the rapidly spreading reapers before they eliminate all the vampires and take over the human race. Cast includes: Luke Goss, Ron Perlman, Leonor Varela, Norman Reedus.

results.title: Blade
results.creator_credit: Amen Ra Films, Peter Frankfurt, Wesley Snipes, Robert Engelman and Stephen Norrington
results.brief_description: This very sleek vampire thriller comes with a strange trio of superheroes. Whistler (Kris Kristofferson), a terminally ill motor mechanic whose lost his family to vampires; haematologist Karen (N’Bushe Wright) who carries the vampire blood but has the medical background to cure herself, and Blade (Wesley Snipes), part human and part vampire since he became infected while in his mother’s womb. Blade’s DNA holds the key to completing the Blood Tide - an event that will turn the rest of the population into vampires. Deacon Frost (Stephen Dorff), arch enemy of Blade and an upstart wannabe vampire (Frost became a vampire after being bitten and is not one of the pure breeds who has been a blood sucker since birth), is leading the charge to achieve Blood Tide, and he has the support of vampires to achieve it. Only 3 people stand in his way. From the opening sequence of the film that depicts a nightclub with a difference, this vibrant mixture of martial arts and rock video provides a very different take on the vampire genre. Cast also includes Donal Logue, Udo Kier and Traci Lords. Based on characters included in “Marvel comics”.

results.title: Blackbeard the pirate
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Edmund Grainger and Raoul Walsh
results.brief_description: Shot in Technicolour, this rousing swashbuckler set in the 17th century tells the story of Blackbeard who, while pillaging the high seas kidnaps the adopted daughter of Sir Henry Morgan, a high official in Jamaica, much to the dismay of her lover, an officer in the British navy. Swordplay and derring-do abound as the timid officer must fight to win back his love, even as Blackbeard duels with his arch-enemy Morgan, who is also a reformed pirate.

results.title: Blackbeard's ghost
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Productions and Robert Stevenson
results.brief_description: The legendary pirate Blackbeard is cursed to wander in limbo until he performs a good deed. He gets his chance when he decides to help a local college track team that hasn’t a ghost of a chance of winning! Cast includes Peter Ustinov, Dean Jones, Suzanne Pleshette, Elsa Lanchester. Based on the book by Ben Stahl.

results.title: Black widow
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Harold Schneider and Bob Rafelson
results.brief_description: A fascinating reworking of the film noir genre, with Teresa Russell performing the femme fatale Reni, who seduces then murders a string of unsuspecting men, and Debra Winger taking on the role of the unsatisfied FBI agent Alex. Alex’s investigation is complicated by her increasing obsession with Reni and the sexual tension between the two, which threatens to bring about the downfall of both. A gripping and intricate film that raises interesting questions about love, desire and death.

results.title: Black Orpheus = Orfeu negro
results.creator_credit: Lopert Films, Sacha Gordine and Marcel Camus
results.brief_description: Orfeu Negro is an transposition of the story of Orpheus and Euridyce to the modern city of Rio da Janeiro during the Carnival. It is interpreted by a cast of non-professional actors. (Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1959 - Palme d’or ; Academy Awards 1959 - Best Foreign Film) Cast includes Breno Higeno-Mello, Marpessa Dawn, Lourdes de Oliveira, Lea Garcia, Alexandro Constantino, Waldemar da Souza, Jorge Dos Santos and Aurino Cassanio. In Portugese with English subtitles.

results.title: Black Narcissus
results.creator_credit: GFD, Archers Film Productions, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger
results.brief_description: Obstacles in the life of a nun’s community high in the Himalayas range from a cynical British agent, suspicious natives, longings of the flesh, problems of faith and insanity to the arduous surrounding terrain. The mission prospers, but often at the expense of spiritual progress and although the nuns eventually retreat from the mission and the threatening terrain it is with a sense of having achieved some small spiritual gains. “One of the few genuinely erotic films to emerge from these sexually staid isles” said one critic. The glorious Oscar winning photography was a trick because it was shot in a London studio and backyard garden. The title refers to the intoxicating perfume worn by Indian Prince Sabu in his last major role. Based on the novel by Rumer Godden. Stars Deborah Kerr, David Farrar, Sabu, Jean Simmons, Flora Robson and Esmond Knight.

results.title: Black eye
results.creator_credit: Pat Rooney Production, Pat Rooney and Jack Arnold
results.brief_description: Since being forced to give up his police badge following a suspension from duties, Shep Stone (Fred Williamson) has tried his hand at P.I work. Arriving home to his apartment one evening Stone finds a murder victim, and a killer waiting. Cast includes Fred Williamson, Rosemary Forsyth, Teresa Graves and Floy Dean. Based on the novel “Murder on the wild side” by Jeff Jacks.

results.title: Black belt Jones
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Fred Weintraub, Paul Heller and Robert Clouse
results.brief_description: Pop Boyd (Scatman Crothers) owns a thriving karate school near downtown Los Angeles. Unfortunately it sits on a piece of land upon which the local mob wants to build its own ‘civic centre’. When the gangsters’ muscling of Pop leads to tragedy, Black Belt Jones (Jim Kelly) steps forward to exact his own brand of lightning-charged revenge. Filmmaker Robert Crouse, who showcased Bruce Lee in ‘Enter the dragon’ and Jackie Chan in ‘The big brawl’, serves up masterful action sequences in which every move is choreographed like a ballet. Cast also includes Gloria Hendry, Eric Laneuville, Alan Weeks, Andre Philippe and Vincent Barbi. See also ‘Game of death’ (1978), ‘Enter the dragon’ (1973), ‘The big brawl’ (1980).

results.title: Bitter moon = Lunes de fiel
results.creator_credit: Les Films Alain Sarde, Canal+, R P Productions, Timothy Burrill Productions and Roman Polanski
results.brief_description: This dark-humored comedy drama explores perverse sexual obsession in a marriage based on mutual hatred. While on a luxury cruise to Istanbul a repressed English couple, Nigel and Fiona, (played by Hugh Grant and Kristin Scott-Thomas) meet a crippled American writer and his beautiful French wife. As the American entertains Nigel with elaborate accounts of the sexual power games he and his wife play (related in lengthy flashbacks), the English couple’s curiosity is aroused. Gradually they become drawn into their twisted and ultimately destructive relationship as unwitting observers and participants in a tragedy with the most extraordinary outcome. Cast also includes Peter Coyote and Emmanuelle Seigner.
